Scientific American magazine (if I remember correctly) had an article years ago (probably in the 1980s or 1990s) about this exact subject, the physics of falling cats landing on their feet. They found the same explanation, basically that the cat has two cylindrical halves of its body with different rotational axes. Angular momentum is conserved when you sum the total rotation of the two halves and the cat as a whole.

Destin, I would like to challenge and/or add to your explanation. First, I enjoy your videos very much. Back to the cats. I think the flexure of the back is very important, and I picture the front and rear of the cat like the two rotors of a helicopter with with two main rotors. Coincidentally, any tail might also serve as a minor "tail" rotor. With the back bent, the whole body of the cat rotates in one direction, but opposite ends - viewed from their respective ends - are rotating in opposite directions, maintaining zero total angular momentum - and actually applying torque against one another (because of the division into two articulated axes the back bend provides). I think the back needs to bend at least a little bit, but the more bend the back can produce, I think the faster the cat can rotate. I would really like to hear your thoughts.

I don't recall if I commented before but the reversed slo-mo looks just like a trampoline maneuver called "Seat-half-twist-seat". You can bounce sitting ("L" shaped) then rise into a full vertical position with your arms swinging up over your head. Then, you spin when they are vertical over your head. The momentum of your arms moving in a circle appears to allow a torque on your body which gets reversed to stop the rotation when you spin after the half-twist.

you can actually learn this if you have a trampoline. its quite easy but it looks awesome enough that most people cant figure out how you did it.
As a kids we did stuff like sitting or lay down while jumping, later even backflips etc.


for the cat flip you jump, let yourself fall down on your butt and while going up again you do this strange arm wave the cat does while your feet just reach out down again (helps you spin like ballerina)
best effect is when you land on your butt again. sit down, wiggle, next sit is 180° flipped. :)
the difficult part are your arms... how do i explain better lol ... arms straight in front of you, lift it so that both hands go up like a la ola wave but not straight in front of you so the hands are both over your right (or left) shoulder. at that point you are completely straight, arms up, legs long, like almost standing, you should have enough spin to sit down again completely the other way around.

You still missed it.
The cat bends its body into a U-shape.
Since the cat made a U shape with its whole body, this creates a twisting motion throughout its whole body.

It's like grabbing a flexible hose with two hands, palms up.
Bend the hose into a U-shape, so your palms are directed toward each other.
Now curl your wrists so your fingers come toward your body.
See how the tube twists within the outline of the U-shape?

You will also notice that at the beginning of the drop, before the cat twisted, his head and tail were tucked inward, making the U-shape Concave.
His belly was facing up, toward the center of the U.
But as the cat fell, he pointed his head and tail toward the outside of the U-shape, making his body Convex.
Now his belly is facing down, and his back points toward the center of the U.

Once his belly is down, and his feet are pointed outward, all he has to do is bring his paws together and land on his feet.

His tail only helps him keep his balance, they way he would if he were walking on a fence, but it doesn't help him "twist".

I actually question his conclusion in this video. I wonder if the arching back has something to do with it.


If you think about it, two cylinders placed end-to-end connected by a central axis, can not rotate in the same direction in free-fall except by initiating a counter-rotation in the axle (this equates to what he was saying about the tail rotating part way through the video).


However, if you were to create a joint in the connecting axis so that you can bend the 2 cylinders to be parallel, and then rotate them, while they are spinning the same direction relative to the central axis, they are actually rotating in opposite directions relative to each other, and thus conserving angular momentum relative to the reference frame.

The tail does help in the cat's turning. It's about conservation of momentum. The cat's tail has to spin in opposite direction to ensure the butt portion of the body to turn to face the ground. You can try by sitting on a spinning chair, feet off the ground. By holding your both arms 90° to your chest, and move both arms to the right, your body moves to the right due to Conservation of Momentum. Same goes to the cat, in 'Non-friction' environment, the tail has to spin the opposite direction in order to turn the butt

FYI for the PETA folks with karmic ailments, a house cat can survive a fall from any height. Cats can also survive falls 20+ stories from buildings, over 50% of the time. They have an amazing ability to absorb the shock of high-impact g-force. When a cat falls that far, they will most likely break a leg or more. It's never pretty. Quite terrifying if you see yours take such a plunge. But rarely they will be unscathed. If your cat falls 24 stories, it will be injured but it should survive. Just get her to the vet STAT! After learning that, it blew my mind. In vertical cities on beautiful days, people leave windows open and sometimes the kitty will not realize how far the ground always is. Mine should be grateful that I live in a 1 story house.

I'm just one of those dudes who was raised with cats, our first kitty had 2 litters, and what can I say. Freakin love all cats. Got one of those "life's better with a cat" magnet on the car. If I lived alone, I'd have at least 5 kitties no doubt. But my two suit me perfectly. My adorable black scaredy cat and deep-personality orange tabby...best of friends too. Got them at the shelter and they bonded like siblings. With cats, you gotta get lucky with adopting 2+ from the shelter. They'll either love or hate one another. But I had a pitbull when I first adopted them and they were 6 & 7 months old. They only had each other at first because everything else was too foreign. Within a month, my tabby was literally curling up and sleeping with my pitbull Max. I have videos on my channel to prove it. Cats are the best.

I've repeatedly watched cats jump up to the tops of wooden fences, and notice that they usually use the same technique; the cat gets within a foot or two of the fence on the ground, looking up, then bounds upward with some contact with its paws on the way up before it gets to the top. But on the other hand, as a kid I dropped my cat because I got tired (with my weak noodle arms) of holding her and thought she'd land on her feet just fine. But she was relaxed and not prepared and she fell on her side (and I felt horrible and never did that again even though she was fine and it was too short a drop to the soft carpet to hurt her). So obviously, one in a million chance, things can happen. So can we all agree to see both sides of the arguement, shake hands, and "don't try this at home, kids"?

I tried this with my cats when they were kittens, and it was interesting to see how they turned their front legs around before their rear legs. I was always careful not to hurt the cats, dropping them on a pillow, but tried dropping them at lower and lower heights until they couldn't turn around in time. Again, being very careful not to let them get hurt in any way. They could get pretty low before they were unable to land on their feet. It was pretty amazing to watch. Now, they both still come to me to get petted, so I know I didn't terrorize them or hurt them. But it's  an interesting experiment. Maybe you should try it with slow motion cameras to pick up what I couldn't!

Dustin,  By forming the "L" shape you can use one leg of the "L" to do the counter rotation.  That leg does not have to rotate itself; it just has to move its mass in a circular path like the tail-style counter rotation would be used.  In the very first drop you can clearly see the "L" and the cat's head turn pretty far around frontward while his back end slightly rotated rearward.
........
There is also a trampoline maneuver called the "Seat Half Twist Seat".  You bounce. legs in front, and do a 180 rotation in the air by swinging your arms forward, up and over your head while also swinging your legs down and through the bottom, spin at the top and continue bringing your arms down in a continuous motion, but now they are again in front of you and your legs back and up also in front of you again. 
I hafta' think about the angular momentum aspect of this, even though I used to do it.
--

This doesn't answer why they do this. It stems from their long ancestral history of being animals that climb – usually trees. The domestic cat still contains whatever suite of adaptations they have that have enable cats to be good up in trees. It only stands to reason that over centuries of climbing they naturally develop the ability to instinctively land on their legs regardless of the position they started from. This is so they can utilize their legs which are are long, muscular and extend under the body rather than straight down, allowing them to absorb the shock when landing.

I like this video; but...Every pregnant woman is advised to avoid contact with cats, as her unborn child is at increased risk of birth defects due to toxoplasmosis if parasites from cats cross the placenta. People are more likely to get toxoplasmosis from eating raw meat or from gardening. Toxoplasmosis can cause mental disorders, such as bipolar disorder and schizophrenia i.e. make you crazy...The following recommendations will help cat owners to reduce their risk of contracting toxoplasmosis. -Avoid undercooked meat.
-Wash all uncooked vegetables thoroughly.
-Wash all cutting boards and utensils that might have come in contact with meat before using them.
-Wear gloves when gardening or working in soil for other reasons. If you don't wear gloves, wash your hands thoroughly afterward.
-Ask your spouse, friends, or neighbors to help out with litter box duties while you're pregnant.
-If you don't have help to keep the litter box clean, wear rubber gloves when changing the litter and thoroughly wash your hands afterward.
-Have your cat's litter changed on a daily basis.
-Keep your cat indoors.

The explanation is so easy..., no tail no rotation! Once the cat is released its tail rotate in the opposite direction its body does! It does not violate the angular momentum law since the momentum due to the fast rotation of the tail in one direction is canceled by the rotation of the body in the other direction.  If you were able for the sake of science to release a cat without tail it will fail to turn and will land right on its back hurting it! Do this simple experiment..., sit on a rotating chair (swivel chair) and grab a rotating object like a bike wheel. It should have some handles to grab it on its rotating axis. Ask someone to rotate fast the wheel and then raise your feet. Try to turn the wheel and see what happens..., magic, magic?? No, it is the same principle the cat applies to turn in the middle of the air..., ANGULAR MOMENTUM CONSERVATION.

As cool as this experiment is, I performed possibly a more interesting one.  I wanted to see how low a cat can be to the ground and still flip over.

Although I have no video proof, my experiment came up with an estimate of one inch.  Completely upside down, with their back one inch off the ground, a cat can still flip over and land on their paws.  Lower than that, there isn't enough space for their paws and they land on their side instead.

Why can't the cat do the same about a single axis of rotation, I mean by not arching its back? Even in that case, by stretching its forelegs in and hindlegs out, the cat can change its radii of rotation at the front and the rear (thereby changing its moment of inertia), though about the same axis this time. And its body can still be divided into two masses even in this case, to adjust the moments of inertia. Is it not possible about the same axis (since that same axis can also be visualized as two axes coinciding)?

I think that's not the whole story. It looks like an alligator roll partly. Consider a metal pipe with an universal in the middle:
===x===
To flip it over, it could be bent in the middle:
|| ||
|| ||
 X
then, one side could be rotated 180 deg. clockwise and the other 180 deg. counter clockwise, but because they are rotating opposite directions angular momentum is conserved. Now the sides that were facing each other are not facing outward. At this point the pipe can straiten out again and it will be opposite side down from the original orientation.
What the cat flip again, and notice how the cat puts it's legs in, bends, and then rotates both halves of it's body outward.

The cat doesn't fold in half completely, and it uses the elements that were mentioned in the video to assist the flip.

You are showing part 1 of my prrof for an existing anti-gravity device: 

Law No. 1: Cats land on their feet
Law No. 2: Buttered sandwiches land on the buttered side

If Cats are buttered on their back and dropped, they simply do not fall because if the fell, Law 1 or Law 2 would be violated. 
This is the proof of an existing Anti-Gravity Device. 

It is easy to proof: 
Grab a Cat, butter it on the back and when you come back from the emergency room lift it up with your bandaged hands and let it drop.
See? The cat won't fall. It foats in mid air, only loosely attached to your bandaged hands with 20 claws...

Cats also have interlocking vertebrae with a lot of cartilage between each one, which helps them right themselves so quickly.  I articulated a cat skeleton for an art project and learned more than I thought possible doing so.  I only found one clavicle, which was about 0.5mm in thickness.  They just float in the muscle tissue.

Back in the day,so many dead cats were found on the side walks that New York City paid a research firm to do a study to find out why. They found that 9 out of 10 cats that fall from window ledges in New York City actually survive. Their body weight and drag coefficient contribute to a terminal velocity that enables them to orientate themselves and land in a way that maximizes shock absorption ( as long as the drop is not above the 8th floor. This statistic is where "9 lives" came from. One out of ten is found dead at the scene.

Another thing I saw that can explain why the cat can turn is that it bends itself into a U (visible at 1:10). Now, most of the momentum will be along the vertical axes (not along the horizontal anymore), and in opposite directions as well for the front and the back part of the body. So by rotating both the front part and the back part of the body at once, the total momentum almost cancels out to zero. Then after it it finished rotating it unbends itself from the U.

I'm not convinced by this explanation. I'm not wholly skeptical of it either, but I have doubts. I think the proposed conservation-of-angular-momentum idea is one way it could be done, but I don't think it's the way that it is done. A straight cylinder can't just make itself roll, except by the divide-in-articulated-halves-and-extend-mass-from-the-axis method. But a V-shaped cylinder can turn fairly easily with coordinated contractions. And that's what the cat is doing. It reverses which aspect "faces in" to the V, then straightens. The role played by angular inertia/momentum is that accelerating the mass at the ends of the V is 'harder' than accelerating the mass around the longitudinal axis. You would have a slight precession of the V caused by the rotation, but it's essentially stable in that plane. You'd have to do the math to prove it, but I don't think you'd get anything like the speed or control needed from extending one set of limbs, rotating that half, retracting those limbs, etc. and I don't think that's what we're actually seeing happen in the footage. 

Interestingly, if you look at "cat righting reflex" on wiki, the verbal explanation matches the one given here, but the animation illustrates 'my' theory, and leaves out all the business with the moment of inertia of the legs etc, entirely.

Hey, Destin, I watched these flipping cat videos with interest and I loved them. They also got me thinking. You mention at the end that a cat's physiology helps them, because they don't have clavicles and their spines are very flexible. I love pet cats, and I also love pet mice and rats, and mice and rats also don't have clavicles and are very flexible. I wondered if my pet mice (I don't have any rats right now) could do the same aerial maneuver. So I tried it with my calmer pet mouse, Moose.

I think that a better testing ground is zero gravity, because in a freefall you get air resistance which makes it easy to spin around from falling at rest (the friction would be an external force great enough to make a difference).  At slow falling speeds (like in this video) it resembles zero gravity much more than a freefall.  I think someone in the space station should try it, that would make for a cool video.

I agree, opinions can't be invalid unless they are one like, "I think that the Earth is the center of the solar system!" That would be invalid, because it contradicts solid fact. In a debate where there are multiple sides and no absolute truth, however, everyone is entitled to an opinion, no matter HOW stupid or misguided it may be. So here is the equation we are looking for: Weight = Coefficient of drag*Cat Area*[(1/2)(air density)(velocity^2)], or symbolically, W = CD*A*[(1/2)(rho)(v^2)]. Solving for V, we get V = sqrt[2*W/(CD*A*rho)]. By examining this equation, we can see that if the cat is light weight and has lots of drag (long fur) its terminal velocity will be lower than a heavy cat with short hair (lower drag coefficient). However, if the cat is fat, its area will larger, which we can see, will slow it down.

A cat (or anything else) will reach terminal velocity when its aerodynamic drag force equals its gravitational force. The force of gravity, Fg, on the cat is its weight (the mass of the cat multiplied by the acceleration of gravity, which, for our purposes is about 32 feet/second^2). This cat probably weighs in at around 9 lbs.

Well, humans can't do that.  And the way the cat lands is actually the same as an Army paratrooper though.  The cat will land with the balls of its feet, then it's feet, and finally its legs and then hunches and finally body.  It is normally a five point landing for humans and animals like the cat when falling going balls of feet, feet, calves, thighs and then the rest of the body.  This helps prevent shock and bones from crushing/grinding together that would cause them to break.  Science MOFO

"(3)The circumstances to which it is relevant to have regard when applying subsection (1) include, in particular—
(a)any lawful purpose for which the animal is kept, and
(b)any lawful activity undertaken in relation to the animal.
(4)Nothing in this section applies to the destruction of an animal in an appropriate and humane manner."

(2)For the purposes of this Act, an animal's needs shall be taken to include—
(a)its need for a suitable environment,
(b)its need for a suitable diet,
(c)its need to be able to exhibit normal behaviour patterns,
(d)any need it has to be housed with, or apart from, other animals, and
(e)its need to be protected from pain, suffering, injury and disease.

"Duty of person responsible for animal to ensure welfare

(1)A person commits an offence if he does not take such steps as are reasonable in all the circumstances to ensure that the needs of an animal for which he is responsible are met to the extent required by good practice."
Where in the aforementioned act does it state that dropping a cat in the manner depicted in this video is abuse?

"Breach of a provision of this Code is not an offence in itself but, if proceedings are brought against you for an offence under Section 9 of the Act, the Court will look at whether or not you have complied with the Code in deciding whether you have committed an offence."

"The purpose of this Code is to provide practical guidance to help owners of cats comply with the provisions of Section 9 of the Act. It does not tell you precisely how to care for a cat, but summarises important things you should consider when making decisions about how best to care for your cat."

"There are codes of practice for the welfare of dogs, cats, horses (including other equidae) and privately kept non-human primates. They provide owners and keepers with information on how to meet the welfare needs of their animals, as required under the Animal Welfare Act 2006. They can also be used in courts as evidence in cases brought before them relating to poor welfare. The codes apply to England only (Wales and Scotland have their own equivalent codes), and are in force from 6 April 2010."

Great, but I think your explanation slightly glosses the point of the flex. You need to get the angular momentum. Pulling and pushing limbs would make the two halves rotate at different speeds, but not generate the motion. The motion is generated from a twisting the flexion of the back (on the side-view note the back legs move rapidly out in the *opposite* direction to the spin, then are brought in-axis before rotating back into line). I know you said flex was important, but not quite why.

Don't think of yourself as one object. Rather, you are many objects that are flexibly connected together. Even if there is nothing around you in the universe, if you are spinning then some parts of you are spinning differently than others (different distance from center of rotation). You would be rotating relative to yourself. Giving a name to that which we don't understand is really just a lexical convenience for the imaginative mind. (cont...)

One can believe anything for any reason - it doesn't make it valid. Also, just because we don't know something YET is no reason to replace that unknown with god. That stifles progress & it's intellectually lazy & dishonest. If instead of learning about the universe we simply shrugged & called every mystery god, we'd still think diseases are caused by evil spirits. Without understanding the intricacies of quantum mechanics modern computing would be impossible. Be patient, we learn more every day.

That brings up another interesting point.  Cats that fall from 7 stories or less sustain greater injuries than those that fall from higher heights.  Why?  The cat can feel itself falling, and it gets scared and pulls in its paws.  but from mhigher than 7 floors, the cat hits terminal velocity.  It no longer feels like it's falling so it spreads its paws out, offering more wind resistance, and slows its fall, so it doesn't hit the ground as hard.

So the arch in the back provides oblique 'axes' for rotation of front and back halves of the cat. This obliqueness means that once the cat begin to fall at least one (probably both) of those  axes must already be rotating - even though the cat was drop with 'no-rotation' (i.e. 'hanging')

The cat's coordinated limb movements then alter this initially uniform spin - giving differential rates at back and front and, by reversing the sequence of motions, it goes from 'zero' to 'spin' back to 'zero'

Welcome to servers 101. My name is rab236 and I will be your professor today. Youtube has many servers in many areas. It also has a special algorithm to differentiate between genuine views and those that are not genuine (a bunch of views from the same location, a very short time on the page, and many other factors). After 300 or so views, Youtube halts the view counter and looks over the views coming in from each server. After a while, the view counter is unlocked and the counter will go up.

A population can only stop evolving if there is:

1. Random Mating
2. No mutation
3. No natural(or artificial) selection
4. An infinitely large population
5. No gene flow (immigration/emigration)

Because cat populations don't meet these criteria, then they must still be evolving.
